title: Synthetic Recap
body:
**Cavaliers Rout Knicks as Price Delivers Masterclass at the Garden**

NEW YORK – On a night defined by a singular, breathtaking performance, the Cleveland Cavaliers authored a stunning 93-73 road victory over the New York Knicks. The story, however, was not the final score, but the historic virtuosity of one man: Mark Price.

The Cavaliers’ guard was simply sublime, etching his name into the annals of Madison Square Garden lore with a game for the ages. Price erupted for a game-high 41 points, a number that fails to capture the surgical precision of his outing. He was flawless from the charity stripe, a perfect 17-for-17, and electrified the court with a blistering 6-for-11 from beyond the arc. Every time the Knicks threatened to mount a challenge, Price had an answer—a dagger three-pointer or an unerring drive to the basket.

While Price’s scoring was the main event, his all-around command of the game was equally impressive. He dished out 8 assists, orchestrating the Cavaliers’ offense with a maestro's touch, and chipped in 4 rebounds for good measure.

The Knicks, by contrast, had no answer. Patrick Ewing managed a team-high 21 points and 10 rebounds, but New York’s offense sputtered and stalled against a Cavaliers defense energized by their leader’s offensive explosion. The home crowd, often a raucous sixth man, was gradually silenced by the relentless efficiency of the visiting guard.

In the end, this was more than a win; it was a declaration. Mark Price didn’t just beat the Knicks; he dismantled them with one of the most efficient and dominant guard performances ever witnessed on the league’s grandest stage. For one night in 1997, the Garden belonged to him.
